componenttext: Sure. Boy, I wish had a better answer or a more complete answer to those questions. So we're still very proud of the site redesign that we've done. We think the user experience is much better. We've added a lot of photos to the site. That always sorts of enhances usability and customer feedback. It's darn hard for me to tie that to the growth in hotel shoppers. We see growth across all of our significant channels, be it free search, paid search, e-mail and indirect, pretty much anything that amounts to a meaningful channel that we source, is growing and it is growing in just about every corner of the world. So international growing faster than our U.S. point-of-sale as we've otherwise shared with you. So again, across the board, probably mildly affected by, I'd say probably, it's really just a guess on my part, affected by the ongoing challenges in Southern Europe. But I can't really point to the decluttering being the reason why our traffic has grown. With regard to Google's activity, the second part of your question, we certainly see them in the search results with their hotel finder occupying the very top position for frequent, for major city hotel searches. We can't, at the moment, see a meaningful loss of traffic to us because of that. Again, that's not to say it couldn't happen in the future and it's possible that we just can't measure it well enough to know it yet and of course, they are just starting to roll that out. So we would expect more coming in that direction. Of course, we've used the product ourselves as well and when you look at what it does versus the rich community that we provide, we're not particularly concerned if the customer were to give both products a try.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: And if I could just follow-up with one thing and I may have missed this on CPC so I apologize, but could you talk about what your outlook is for the year relative to the flattish that you previously indicated?
componenttext: And if I could just follow-up with one thing and I may have missed this on CPC so I apologize, but could you talk about what your outlook is for the year relative to the flattish that you previously indicated?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess Julie had mentioned. It's hard for us to forecast this because, as you know, we don't set the prices. Our clients come to us on occasion and say, they want to be it more for in certain parts of the traffic that we can supply. So as we look forward
componenttext: I guess Julie had mentioned. It's hard for us to forecast this because, as you know, we don't set the prices. Our clients come to us on occasion and say, they want to be it more for in certain parts of the traffic that we can supply. So as we look forward, we're saying at Q1, it was slightly better and I emphasize slightly, which is great news, that it wasn't down a lot and we weren't forecasting it to be up a lot. So it hasn't really changed when we look forward. It definitely changed our forecast or that part of our model has not changed going forward.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012

componenttext: I guess on your selling and marketing line, any color you can give I guess between the direct and the indirect breakout? And I guess specifically looking to see if I can get any comments from you about just sort of the U.S. versus foreign market spending. I guess where are you in terms of those markets where you guys might be more aggressively seeding kind of a local content from the local population?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So this past quarter, the breakout between direct and indirect was 70%, 30%, which is consistent with what we saw last quarter and for all of last year. And the international spend, which we don't break out specifically, international expansion is d
componenttext: Sure. So this past quarter, the breakout between direct and indirect was 70%, 30%, which is consistent with what we saw last quarter and for all of last year. And the international spend, which we don't break out specifically, international expansion is definitely one of our key long-term growth strategies. And so as you can imagine, a good part of that spend is directed towards international growth.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Nathaniel Schindler from Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nathaniel Schindler from Bank of America.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I want to ask you a little bit more on the traffic detail. Have you seen any correlation between increased content in the site and acceleration in unique user growth? Also, on your domestic versus international growth, is your domestic growth at 12% in th
componenttext: I want to ask you a little bit more on the traffic detail. Have you seen any correlation between increased content in the site and acceleration in unique user growth? Also, on your domestic versus international growth, is your domestic growth at 12% in the U.S. roughly? And 17% for last year. While international is growing roughly 3x faster than that with roughly what, 2x the traffic? Is this just a catch-up in the monetization of the international traffic, in which case you would expect it to go look more like the U.S. once that monetization has occurred? Or is there something else? And can you characterize a little bit more about traffic growth you saw on 30% hotel shoppers. How that growth looked within the U.S.?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good questions. I'll try to take note as we went along. So in order, certainly we do see content growth related to overall traffic growth, the more visitors we have, this has always been true. The more visitors, the more review contributions we have and t
componenttext: Good questions. I'll try to take note as we went along. So in order, certainly we do see content growth related to overall traffic growth, the more visitors we have, this has always been true. The more visitors, the more review contributions we have and that's part of our challenge when we start in brand-new markets, where we have not a lot of traffic, we don't get a lot of reviews and we need to jumpstart that process. We've since, especially over the past 12 months or so, done a fair amount of focus on helping to reward our members with badges and such to help get them more engaged in our community, to write more reviews and we certainly have seen that pay off with higher reviews per user contribution rate. So we've proven to ourselves, at least that if you spend a little bit more time engaging with our members, we can get more content out of it. To your second question, the relative U.S. growth. So it is a little more complicated. When we looked at this and asked the same question ourselves, it is a little more complicated than on the face value. One of the things that's going on is when we look at U.S. visitors, I'll be even clearer. When we look at people who live in the U.S. and they're coming to tripadvisor.com usually, and the growth rate there is actually higher than that sort of 12% might imply. But the traffic on, but then you asked why is the traffic on tripadvisor.com isn't growing as much. And the answer is or partial answer is we have a fair amount of traffic over the past year that was coming from other English-speaking parts of the world. Canada, U.K., Ireland, Australia, India, that had been ending up on tripadvisor.com and so we would count it as domestic revenue because it's off of our dot com site. We've seen very strong growth in our non-dot com English language sites recently. And so part of that delta in international growth versus U.S. growth is actually, to some degree, it's English speakers who live outside of the U.S. now going to their local point-of-sale. Now, when we were buying our traffic through SCM, we would normally buy it through the appropriate point of sale, so no change there. But Google's algorithm over the past year has changed and it's favored local points of sale more. We have lots of local points-of-sale, so the Australian citizens are now hitting TripAdvisor.com.au instead of TripAdvisor.com. You see that in international revenue going up. We see it as revenue that was on dot com moving over to Australia. From a commerce perspective, it is neutral to us because when that Australian was visiting TripAdvisor.com, they were seeing Australian commerce partners, the local OTAs in Australia anyways. So it's just the way we're measuring it ending up on different points of sale. Finally, we do have a very active sales force in all parts the world that are constantly signing up more hotel chains and more of the local OTAs. It's just the fact that whenever we have more inventory in a given country, more properties that we can have our actual prices but not activated for and more choose initial prices because we don't just have 2 OTAs. We have 4. We don't have just one supplier and one OTA, we have a supplier and 3 OTAs, we make more money. That's the choice aspect that we strive for. And in Q1, just like in prior quarters, we added more choice on newer points of sales. That improves the monetization rates. So we make a bit more money on international IPs. And I think that covered all 3 of the questions.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Peter Stabler from Wells Fargo securities.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could provide a little bit more color on DaoDao, Kuxun, the level of your investment in China and whether you can give us any sort of magnitude of loss on your investment there and maybe what kind of ramp you are looking at toward profita
componenttext: Wondering if you could provide a little bit more color on DaoDao, Kuxun, the level of your investment in China and whether you can give us any sort of magnitude of loss on your investment there and maybe what kind of ramp you are looking at toward profitability in that market.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Certainly, Peter. It's a very good question. We've sort of discussed it internally. Unfortunately, we're not ready to disclose that, the loss and the path to profitability numbers yet. We're continuing to work on a couple of meaningful initiatives in that
componenttext: Certainly, Peter. It's a very good question. We've sort of discussed it internally. Unfortunately, we're not ready to disclose that, the loss and the path to profitability numbers yet. We're continuing to work on a couple of meaningful initiatives in that part of the world and identifying additional ways where we can bring, the work we're putting into both sites into a more common framework, if you will. We do continue to lose money there. We will continue to invest because we see the price there being quite meaningful in the model. We certainly believe will work in China. At this point, Kuxun is doing quite well on the flight side, certainly a strength in that part of the business as they hooked up with a lot of individual agents, as well as several OTAs to really help the clients find the better price than what they can do on other sites. And on DaoDao again, the focus remains on helping user find the best hotel and overall the best travel experience. We're starting to leverage some of our additional worldwide sales activities because there's a lot of other Western hotel companies looking to break into the China market and we're a company that they're used to dealing with. And of course, the domestic travel on the outbound trip, as everyone would tell you, is more valuable than the domestic traveler, even though much smaller number but a more valuable commodity. And we have, far and away, the most reviews of anyone when you look at the entire set of places that Chinese outbound traveler would go to. So we remain optimistic but not a lot of detail I can report in terms of progress.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Herman Leung from Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Herman Leung from Susquehanna.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions, I guess. First, on your hotel shopper trends, you talked about much stronger-than-expected growth of 30%. I was wondering if you can kind of give us a context of how that growth has progressed, I guess, compared to last year's seasona
componenttext: Two quick questions, I guess. First, on your hotel shopper trends, you talked about much stronger-than-expected growth of 30%. I was wondering if you can kind of give us a context of how that growth has progressed, I guess, compared to last year's seasonality and how that's progressing in the first quarter and early into the second. And then second is on volume and pricing growth, you talked about a little bit of pricing growth that you're seeing today and I know that it's predicated on a lot of the competitive bidding, but wondering what your guidance today implies from a pricing and volume standpoint.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I don't have offhand kind of a monthly image of the hotel shopper growth last year. I do recall our February call, where it was looking a lot darker at that time, when we were looking at our January hotel shopper growth. So January was a tougher
componenttext: Sure. So I don't have offhand kind of a monthly image of the hotel shopper growth last year. I do recall our February call, where it was looking a lot darker at that time, when we were looking at our January hotel shopper growth. So January was a tougher start when we looked at overall numbers as best we could tell. And then the quarter looked like the quarter did get better. We also did make some monetization improvements over the course of the quarter. So the hotel shoppers was a challenge to monetization of the hotel shoppers, as we were still pulling out of the site redesign and we're pleased to report that we were able to make some monetization progress, i.e. the 30% of the hotel shoppers that were visiting earlier in the quarter were converting less, and by the end of the quarter, they were stronger, so we were able to recover some of that loss. The CPC growth, I really wouldn't counsel, or I can say we are not modeling a growth in CPC over the course of the rest of the year. And again, it's a bidding model, as I've said but we'd be quite comfortable assuming a price increase as we look forward.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chad Bartley from Pacific Crest.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chad Bartley from Pacific Crest.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Slightly different questions on the Expedia and the redesign topics and I guess headwinds, I think. Earlier in the year, you talked about Expedia and the CPCs there being a headwind to growth of about 5 points. Site redesign being a headwind to growth of
componenttext: Slightly different questions on the Expedia and the redesign topics and I guess headwinds, I think. Earlier in the year, you talked about Expedia and the CPCs there being a headwind to growth of about 5 points. Site redesign being a headwind to growth of about 2 to 3 points. And it seems like for us perhaps that's a little conservative, and I'm curious what your new results and what your new guidance implies as far as headwinds from those 2 topics?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Chad. As I say, we've seen that the CPC headwind from Expedia was balanced by the site redesigns and in fewer lower value clicks, combined with the pricing moves of our clients. So net-net, we're back to a flat number. So when we look forwar
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Chad. As I say, we've seen that the CPC headwind from Expedia was balanced by the site redesigns and in fewer lower value clicks, combined with the pricing moves of our clients. So net-net, we're back to a flat number. So when we look forward, it's kind of all of that site redesign, all of the Expedia transition is behind us and we're just looking forward saying, okay, CPCs, we're modeling flattish going forward and now it's all about the traffic growth and international expansion and the other interesting initiatives that we have. So I guess I'd suggest we leave some of those things behind us and kind of model on Q1 going forward as obviously adjusted for the seasonality of our business.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Olson from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Olson from Piper Jaffray.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Andrew Conner in for Mike. Question is we've seen very impressive RevPAR growth in Latin America during the last several quarters. And we've also seen a very strong correlation between RevPAR and TripAdvisor revenue. So first of all, just curious,
componenttext: This is Andrew Conner in for Mike. Question is we've seen very impressive RevPAR growth in Latin America during the last several quarters. And we've also seen a very strong correlation between RevPAR and TripAdvisor revenue. So first of all, just curious, how do you explain that strong correlation between RevPAR and your guidance revenue? And then second, if you could just talk about the growth rates you're seeing in Latin America and what is really driving that 50% plus rest of the world growth?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean it's a fair question, Andrew. The RevPAR, when the hotelier or when the OTA is making more money because of a lead we send because RevPARs have gone up, they can literally afford to spend more of that. So, if, for example, an OTA is willing t
componenttext: Sure. I mean it's a fair question, Andrew. The RevPAR, when the hotelier or when the OTA is making more money because of a lead we send because RevPARs have gone up, they can literally afford to spend more of that. So, if, for example, an OTA is willing to share 60% of the revenue that they make with us, just as an example, some pay more, some pay less, as that RevPAR goes up, we would see that increase. So if RevPAR is up 5%, it's fair to think of TripAdvisor deserving a 5% increase as our percentage. Do we always get that? No. That's a part of our negotiation with our sales rep and the client and it's part competition for that click, if in any particular country, hoteliers battling against an OTA for the lead, the hotelier has a lot more margin they can offer and RevPAR going up, they can offer even more. They have a bigger piece of the pie than what the OTA has and they might be able to outbid. So again, relatively straightforward correlation with RevPAR, relatively straightforward correlation with booking rates in whatever particular country. If it's a highly engaged online country that has a high online conversion rate, that's great for us as well versus a country where there's a lot of lookers but most of the actual transaction happens off-line, ergo we wouldn't get a lot of credit for those transactions, therefore client wouldn't be able to pay us a lot on a per lead basis. And the other part of your question, the continued growth in our rest of world is really a function of a lot of our initiatives and focus is around driving traffic throughout the globe, really not just in the U.S. but the fact that our U.S. and U.K. points-of-sale are really the most mature, they're the most well-known. So there's just a lot more room to attract new visitors in other markets. And I would expect that overall trend to certainly continue going forward.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just first off, I think people asked it in a couple of different ways, would love to hear your commentary around linearity of growth throughout the quarter. I guess, really how growth especially in CPC revenue both in January versus March, and whether it
componenttext: Just first off, I think people asked it in a couple of different ways, would love to hear your commentary around linearity of growth throughout the quarter. I guess, really how growth especially in CPC revenue both in January versus March, and whether it was kind of fair to assume that that Expedia revenue number got better as we got throughout the quarter, and then the second question, really just around the business listings product and I would just love to step back and Steve, get your thoughts in terms of where that business can go in terms of percent of penetration of the overall market and just thoughts around how you think about potentially sizing that business over time.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. Again, excellent questions. I don't really recall how Expedia's CPCs may have changed Jan, Feb, March. The fact that I don't remember them being on a big upswing or downswing might lead you to fairly believe it wasn't something I was carefull
componenttext: Sure, Brian. Again, excellent questions. I don't really recall how Expedia's CPCs may have changed Jan, Feb, March. The fact that I don't remember them being on a big upswing or downswing might lead you to fairly believe it wasn't something I was carefully watching for any particular reason. So they manage their bids carefully. Again, I can't say one thing for sure or not but it wasn't something I was focused on, certainly. Overall, again it's a bidding environment, so all the other partners are move their things up and down. And we do see a fair amount of fluctuation kind of on a weekly basis, where some are moving up and some are moving down. Our averages tend not to change all that much. To the question on business listings, so we do some simple math on I think it's 570,000 accommodations on the site and we have I think over 1/2 of them as registered owners now. And most of the registered owners are properties that have reviews. And so we qualify by properties that are popular enough to have a bunch of reviews. So the owner has probably heard of TripAdvisor because people have shown up, saying hey, I read about you on TripAdvisor. So there's some knowledge built-in. And then from memory, the different ways we tried to qualify out of that 570,000, it was well over 1/2 that the thought were perfectly reasonable folks would be interested in the business listing subscription. It might've been something closer to 3/4 of our potential and then we take out the properties that really don't have a good reputation on the assumption that most of them probably wouldn't want to pay us for something and we come up with again, well north of a couple hundred thousand viable prospects. We then look and say well, viable prospect for what? Well, we say there's a fixed annual subscription, the telephone number, the e-mail. Then there's the special offers. Then there's the placement on the mobile devices. And then there's incremental eyeballs that we might be able to offer down the road with additional marketing or advertising services. And for these properties, it's pretty hard to be able to identify an audience looking to come in a particular timeframe as we have often for a particular city that are looking for a hotel. Wow. We've got that audience. We have a person doing a search for us for a specific date in a specific city where this hotel is located. So that's already highly qualified customer and services down the road to help each of those individual hoteliers put their unique message in front of those folks. Right now, we have an annual subscription but there's nothing inherent in our business model that says it couldn't be a CPA or a CPC or a CPM additional upsell in the years to come. And then we recognize that we have a ton of additional travelers as I alluded to earlier, who they've already picked out their hotel and now they're looking for something to do or they're looking for something to do first and then they'll find a place to stay or they're trying to figure out where they want to eat when they're on that trip. And all of those have the same dynamic of it's a traveler coming into the local market that the business owner really has a tough time reaching on a timely basis. And you can think of a restaurateur who may put a two-for-one coupon in the concierge desk of a hotel and say hey, I'm willing to offer a two-for-one special to out-of-town guests who are asking the concierge at the hotel where to eat. That's a nice opportunity for the restaurant to get a customer that wasn't already a local. That wasn't already going to be eating there, i.e. the restaurant was going to be giving the two-for-one away to an existing customer. Well, that's the TripAdvisor eyeball as well. So I'm not preannouncing any product, I'm not talking about some functionality the next day but we recognize that all of the business owners who are represented on TripAdvisor and some who are not even represented in TripAdvisor now but have their product or service to sell to the traveler, TripAdvisor is a fantastic kind of media opportunity for them, and with the self-service capabilities we've built, the business listings, with the worldwide sales force, to reach the folks that aren't self-service inclined. We feel we're in a pretty good position to take advantage of those opportunities.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012

componenttextpreview: I have 2 quick ones. First, I want to go back to Herman's question on kind of the hotel shopper growth compares. Because I know that last year, Google made a lot of changes throughout the years, so I was just curious if there's anything that happened with
componenttext: I have 2 quick ones. First, I want to go back to Herman's question on kind of the hotel shopper growth compares. Because I know that last year, Google made a lot of changes throughout the years, so I was just curious if there's anything that happened with the hotel shopper growth trend throughout last year and how we should think about the cost per click growth? Because the compares are due to be easier throughout this year if you're advertising, so is there any reason we should not expect an acceleration in the cost per click growth revenue? And then the second one is in the quarter, just curious is there any impact at all from kind of the Easter shift, the Easter shift being earlier in April this year than last year? And what was the benefit of the leap year?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think I can really only answer the very last question. Leap year probably added 3% to our February revenue. It added one extra day. That's nice. So the hotel shopper growth last year -- I look around, I'm really not sure I can add much color to the noti
componenttext: I think I can really only answer the very last question. Leap year probably added 3% to our February revenue. It added one extra day. That's nice. So the hotel shopper growth last year -- I look around, I'm really not sure I can add much color to the notion of it getting easier just because I don't recall a particular falloff of hotel shoppers. And yes, Google made changes throughout the year but we expect Google to make changes throughout this year as well. So aside from lapping the site redesign in Q4, I don't see any other nonseasonal effect looking over the course of this year that would be material to our numbers.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then, the Easter impact, is there any impact at all in the quarter?
componenttext: And then, the Easter impact, is there any impact at all in the quarter?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it just shifts kind of April traffic to April traffic. So certainly nothing that we've modeled into any of our numbers. And no, I don't think there's any effect.
componenttext: I think it just shifts kind of April traffic to April traffic. So certainly nothing that we've modeled into any of our numbers. And no, I don't think there's any effect.

componenttext: Excellent. Well Again, I want to thank everyone for joining us on our first quarter call. headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 01, 2012
