headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the TripAdvisor Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder this conference is recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Senior Director
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the TripAdvisor Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder this conference is recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Senior Director of Investor Relations, Will Lyons. You may begin.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ashley. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to TripAdvisor's Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. We appreciate your joining us today. I'm Will Lyons, Senior Director of Investor Relations for TripAdvisor, and joining me on the call toda
componenttext:
Thanks, Ashley. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to TripAdvisor's Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. We appreciate your joining us today. I'm Will Lyons, Senior Director of Investor Relations for TripAdvisor, and joining me on the call today are our CEO Steve Kaufer; and our CFO Julie Bradley.
Before we begin, with many of our analysts and investors located in areas impacted by the recent storm, we thought it best to delay our earnings call until today. Our thoughts are with those affected, and we appreciate everyone's patience. 
I'd like to remind you that the estimates and other forward-looking statements included in this call represent the company's view as of today, November 1, 2012. 
These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and involve a number of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. Additional information concerning these factors is contained in TripAdvisor's filings with the SEC, including our annual report filed on Form 10-K, which is available on www.sec.gov. The forward-looking statements included in this call represent the company's views on actual results differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statement. You'll also fire reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP financial measures discussed on this call in our Q3 earnings release, which is available on our IR site, ir.tripadvisor.com. Finally, unless otherwise stated, all represents selling marketing expense, and GeneTitan and technology and content expense, excludes stock-based compensation and all comparisons on this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2011. 
With that, I will now turn the call over to Steve.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Will, and welcome, everyone, to today's conference call. Before starting, on behalf of the entire at TripAdvisor Media Group family, are far so with everyone that has been impacted by here again Sandy. Special thanks goes out to those of you on
componenttext:
Thank you, Will, and welcome, everyone, to today's conference call. Before starting, on behalf of the entire at TripAdvisor Media Group family, are far so with everyone that has been impacted by here again Sandy. Special thanks goes out to those of you on the Northeast Region for joining us today. 
I'm happy to report that TripAdvisor had a strong third quarter. We generated record quarterly revenue of $212.7 million and adjusted EBITDA of $107.1 million. Across the globe, traffic to our site continues to be strong, as total traffic to TripAdvisor sites grew in the mid-30s, and even more importantly, our hotel shoppers have continued to grow at approximately 30% based on our log files.
I'm also pleased that we made great progress this quarter, rapidly innovating the TripAdvisor experience for both our users and our advertising partners alike. 
Our core click-based revenue accelerated, growing 15% year-over-year, based on continued strong hotel shopper growth. This revenue growth can also be attributed to improvements in our on-site conversion and personalization efforts, offset by a still week yet stabilizing Southern European market. Unique to the third quarter, we estimate that the Summer Olympics had a 2% negative impact on hotel shopper traffic in click-based revenue.
We were also pleased to see a 5% to 6% uplift in click-based revenue very late in the quarter, when we left last year's site redesign. We expect this uplift to continue in the coming quarters.
Other most exciting things to see is the continued strong growth in deep engagement of our growing traveler community. Our remarkable members grew to over 70% year-over-year to more than 36 million, fueling our robust and growing e-mail campaigns. Our members love sharing their travel expenses with other travelers and friends, and they continue to share content in 21 different languages at a remarkable rate of more than 60 contributions per minute, which equates to over 30 million contributions in a single year. 
During the third quarter, we were thrilled to announce content syndication agreements with Best Western and with Wyndham Hotels Group. The Wyndham partnership, which has been expanded to 15 of their hotel brands, also includes a review collection agreement, where Wyndham will encourage their guests to share their expenses to a postdate e-mail and survey powered by TripAdvisor. 
Including these latest wins, we now syndicate our travel and reviews to more than 500 major travel partners, including more than 50 hotel chains, reinforcing and enhancing the visibility of the TripAdvisor brand as the fact of standard for travel research.
We also appreciate that tens of thousands of individual business owners around the world proudly display their review on TripAdvisor stickers, their certificates of excellence and the travelers choice plaques on-site at their hotels, restaurants and attractions. The brand fly lease is coming, but the TripAdvisor site accounting for only 10% of online travel uniques, we have a lot of runway left for continued growth and adoption.
In TripAdvisor, we are always innovating our products and extensively testing and discovering new ways to improve site usability and experience for our users. We strive to create the very best experience for every user, on every device, in every geography. You can see this in our social and personalization initiatives, great vehicles to which we learn about our users, their friends and their preferences, all of which enable us to deliver more satisfying, inspiring and customized travel planning experience for everyone.
Along these lines, we continue to leverage the Facebook platform and subsequent to the end of the quarter, we were pleased to welcome aboard, via acquisition, the talented team from Wanderfly, whose focused on blending inspiration, personalization and social nicely complement our ongoing efforts.
In addition to social and personalization, mobile is a key area of focus and investment as we innovate to deliver the best user experience in every device. Year-over-year, we've seen downloads over smartphones and tablets apps more than double, reaching more than 26 million total downloads. Over the same timeframe, our average monthly mobile uniques are up over 130%, more than 35 million according to our own log files. 
We rolled out an improved tablet interface during the quarter and have seen tablet monetization improve nicely since earlier this year. It's now more closely resembling desktop, an important trend, given that tablet comprises about 3/4 of our mobile revenue. 
On the other hand, smartphone monetization isn't growing as quickly as tablet monetization, which is not surprising to us, given the use case and form factor of that device. 
During Q3, we began testing hotel meta display on smartphones, an exciting step towards optimizing the user experience. Similar to our flights product, user interface shows partner prices and availability in line, allowing a hotel shopper to more easily compare booking options. The tests are progressing well. And borrowing any unforeseen challenges, we expect to roll out hotel meta display to all phone traffic later this quarter.
For us, phone is all about optimizing the user experience. And we expect over time, this innovation will drive better user engagement, better conversion and therefore come better monetization on the phone smaller real estate.
Now the logical question to ask is, are we planning to roll out a meta display to all users on all platforms on all geographies? And the answer is we don't know yet. We think the meta experience on phone makes a lot of sense and it's worth testing on desktop, but we aren't making any commitments beyond testing at this point. We've contemplated a meta display for years. And as with all of our product releases, there are 3 main things that we consider: Is it good for the user experience? Is it good for our clients? And what does it do for TripAdvisor economics? We always weigh these factors very carefully, and our objective is to find the solution that works best for all 3.
As it relates to our OTA and hoteliers partners, looking at the global landscape, we've seen improvements throughout Q3, especially in our new international markets. 
In the MEA, we added Germany hotels to our growing list of partners in the Middle East. In APAC, we added 3 new regional Asian OTAs, including Asia rooms. On the bidding side, we started testing property rank reporting with a select set of major OTA clients and 3 test markets in early October. And while the testing has begun, we have not been surprised by any of their results so far.
The goal of providing these results is that allow partners the chance to better understand there are a light on TripAdvisor and help them rationalize higher per unit or per click spend. We expect the test to be successful and expect to have minimum CTC per property thresholds in place in early 2013. At that point, we would consider moving to worldwide roll-out.
Turning our relatively short history as a public company, you've heard us describe a few initiatives we've undertaken to strategically position TripAdvisor for the long-term. 
The site redesign to more traffic quality improvement measures, the data sharing of large partners and our new meta interface on smartphones, we remain focused on optimizing user experience and enhancing client satisfaction and maximizing TripAdvisor economics over the long term. This has been TripAdvisor's DNA since inception.
In summary, we have a great quarter. We're squarely on track to deliver, to achieve our 2012 business objectives and are excited about how we position the business for continued growth in 2013 and beyond.
I'll now turn the call over to Julie, who will provide some color on the Q3 results and our financial outlook.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good afternoon, everyone. Third quarter revenue increased 18% year-over-year to $212.7 million, in line with our expectations. Assuming constant currency, revenue would have been 4% higher. Click-based revenue was up 15% year-over-yea
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good afternoon, everyone. Third quarter revenue increased 18% year-over-year to $212.7 million, in line with our expectations. 
Assuming constant currency, revenue would have been 4% higher. Click-based revenue was up 15% year-over-year to $168 million. When comparing year-over-year hotel shopper growth, approximately 30%, to click-based revenue growth, please note that revenue growth this past quarter was negatively impacted by approximately 5% from foreign exchange; 5% to 6% from last year's site redesign; and 3% to 5% from the spin-related Expedia pricing changes. Additionally, as Steve mentioned, we believe that our hotel shopper traffic and revenue would have been 2% higher, were it not for the lower traffic during the Summer Olympics.
Display-based advertising revenue grew 12% year-over-year to $23.6 million, driven by solid growth in the Americas, offset by weakness in EMEA, due to persistent macroeconomic softness in Southern Europe. Assuming constant currency, display-based revenue would have been 2% higher.
Subscription, transaction and other revenue, which includes business listings, vacation rentals and our transaction businesses, had a solid Q3, growing 53% to $21.1 million. 
In business listings, new sales reps are ramping globally, and we expect to see continued productivity improvements as we enter 2013.
As it relates to geographic mix, despite macroeconomic challenges and unfavorable foreign exchange movement, non-U.S. revenue was 50% of total revenue during the third quarter, compared to 49% in Q2 and 47% in the third quarter of 2011.
In general, we saw a quick growth accelerate in our core market. And on the pricing side, we saw stabilizing to improving pricing abroad. Specifically, in EMEA, we saw accelerating growth in the U.K. despite a persistently tough pricing environment. Also, Southern Europe, although still week, showed encouraging signs of pricing stabilization.
Our newer Russian market remains in hypergrowth mode, albeit growing off a smaller base. In our fast-growing Latin America and APAC market, we saw continued strong hotel shopper growth and solid pricing trend, driven by a stronger coverage, traffic acquisition, brand-building and content collection initiative. Notably, Brazil remains in hypergrowth mode as well. And to put it into perspective, is fast approaching Spain and Italy in terms of click-based revenue.
On the expense side, non-GAAP sales and marketing expenses was $66.5 million, or 31% of revenue for the quarter, consistent sequentially on a percentage of revenue basis. Given that Q4 is our seasonally lowest revenue quarter, we expect to see deleveraging in our non-GAAP sales and marketing spend. This translates into sales and marketing spend in the high 30s to low 40s as a percent of revenue for the fourth quarter, and mid-30s, as a percentage of revenue for full year 2012.
Moving forward, we continue to prior -- prioritize traffic diversification, international expansion, and the hotel shopper growth, as we identify under leveraged marketing channels to meet these growth objectives.
Non-GAAP tech and content expenses were $20.3 million, or 10% of revenue for the quarter, and non-GAAP G&A expenses were $16 million or 8% of revenue. Both were in line with our expectations, and we expect these expense lines to stay relatively constant on a dollar basis in Q4.
Our Q3 effective tax rate of 34.4% was higher than we expected, due to an income mix shift towards jurisdictions with higher statutory rates, as well as an increased in valuation allowance for one of our U.S. subsidiaries. For the balance of 2012, we expect our effective tax rate to remain largely consistent with our year-to-date rates.
Cash flow from operations were strong at $76.5 million or 36% of revenue for the quarter. We continue to expect full year 2012 cash flow from operations to track with adjusted EBITDA after providing for interest and taxes, or low 30s as a percentage of revenue. In terms of headcount, we ended Q3 with 1,483 employees, up from 1,444 employees at June 30, and 1,196 at the end of Q3 2011.
With that, let me turn to our outlook for the balance of the year. Given our year-to-date performance, we continue to expect 2012 total revenue growth in the high-teens. Driven mainly by continued strong hotel shopper growth and the tailwinds created from lapping last year's site redesign, we now expect click-based revenue growth to be in the high-teens for the full year. 
While fourth quarter to date volume and conversion remain strong, pricing continues to be a headwind, given the persistent macroeconomic softness overseas, as well as the fact that we are still comping higher pre spin Expedia pricing. We continue to expect low double-digit annual revenue growth for display-based revenue, as it faces a tough Q4 comp based on unusually strong demand in Q4 2011, which may not reoccur. We also expect full year subscription transaction and other revenue growth to be consistent with our year-to-date results.
Based on our continued profitability outperformance, we now expect full year 2012 adjusted EBITDA growth in the high-single digits. We are in the midst of our 2013 planning process and will provide our expectations for next year on our Q4 calls.
In closing, our year-to-date performance keep us well on track achieve our 2012 goals. We'll now open the call up to your questions.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Mike Olson of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Mike Olson of Piper Jaffray.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Could you just talk a little bit more about kind of the traffic acquisition strategy and how anything you may have changed versus what you talked about last quarter? And ultimately, kind of how we're thinking about it going forward?
componenttext: Could you just talk a little bit more about kind of the traffic acquisition strategy and how anything you may have changed versus what you talked about last quarter? And ultimately, kind of how we're thinking about it going forward?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. Thanks for the question. I'd say we had put the plan in place when we spoke last time in terms of reducing some of the SEM spend on traffic that wasn't profitable when we measured it through the conversions. And that has remained the plan. It
componenttext: Sure, Mike. Thanks for the question. I'd say we had put the plan in place when we spoke last time in terms of reducing some of the SEM spend on traffic that wasn't profitable when we measured it through the conversions. And that has remained the plan. It was a relatively easy change for us to make back then. And so the search engine team has been focused on continuing to grow that channel, and they've had some success. And that's still just one piece of the overall picture. We have essentially all of the different traffic acquisition vehicles and customer acquisition vehicles in terms of e-mail marketable members ongoing with respect to Facebook, affiliates and all the rest of the mechanisms by which we can track traffic to our site. Shorter answer is, not much of a change from prior quarter.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Laura Martin of Needham & Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from Laura Martin of Needham & Company.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to check -- it sounds like maybe we've had some movement on mobile. You said that desktop is 3/4 of total mobile usage. My recollection, my estimate there was about 70% pricing, as a percentage of desktop, and smartphones of about 10% of pri
componenttext: I just wanted to check -- it sounds like maybe we've had some movement on mobile. You said that desktop is 3/4 of total mobile usage. My recollection, my estimate there was about 70% pricing, as a percentage of desktop, and smartphones of about 10% of pricing. It sounds like maybe both of those are getting better. Is that a fair we readthrough from your comments?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, let me try to fare price. We haven't actually shared the specific breakout between desktop and mobile in terms of traffic. What we're saying is the -- when the phrase mobile is used, we often refer to both tablet and phone, and that 3/4 of revenue g
componenttext: Well, let me try to fare price. We haven't actually shared the specific breakout between desktop and mobile in terms of traffic. What we're saying is the -- when the phrase mobile is used, we often refer to both tablet and phone, and that 3/4 of revenue generated from tablet of phones remains on the tablet. We've seen some improvements in our monetization rate on the tablet. That's all good. And it's kind of what I had told you we expected to see over time, as the tablet usage much more closely resembles desktop. On the phone, we haven't seen a meaningful change in the monetization rate i.e., it's still a very small percentage of desktop. And we think it's form factor. We think it's in-market activity. We think it's folks who are thinking about the trip, checking out some hotels and some more -- whatever, who just aren't ready to actually spend the money right then and there because our typical usage pattern is not last-minute landed in the city near your hotel room that some other apps may have. So we've introduced, from a testing perspective, the meta display to the smartphones because we think that's just a much better experience when someone wants to check the prices and do that based or a research. Because we're showing the prices in line, we think the conversion of rate at the leads would be higher downstream, so the overall monetization rate of that display will be better for us. And I'm just cautioning that in that mobile environment. A, it's a small part of our traffic. B, it's clearly monetizing small part of our traffic. So the shift from the current monetization model through a meta display on phone isn't a particularly material financial event for us.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Douglas Anmuth of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Douglas Anmuth of JPMorgan.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just give us some color on the feedback you're getting around the traffic quality changes and the new bidding system? Any feedback from OTAs that you're getting would be helpful.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just give us some color on the feedback you're getting around the traffic quality changes and the new bidding system? Any feedback from OTAs that you're getting would be helpful.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So it's always kind of hard to parse out what they're saying and what you're doing. We've seen some cases where partners have lifted very bids. Is it seasonal? Is it more hungry for reach? Or is it they can afford more because our traffic is better?
componenttext: Sure. So it's always kind of hard to parse out what they're saying and what you're doing. We've seen some cases where partners have lifted very bids. Is it seasonal? Is it more hungry for reach? Or is it they can afford more because our traffic is better? So I don't, unfortunately, an awful lot offer by way of direct feedback. In terms of the big piece, we haven't really changed anything in terms of how partners can bid on our traffic. What we've really done, started to do in these tests markets, is provide more transparency about whether bid currently gets them in terms of their rank reporting. And as I said, we -- some partners have started to use that information. There hasn't been any meaningful changes that we've been able to detect, either up or down, with respect to that having a material impact on us. We can say that the partners that have some of this information are grateful for it. They appreciate as giving into them and it's working their way through their systems as to how they might be able to take advantage of it.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mash of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mash of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: One, your tax rate of 34.5% or even, the 30% that you had historically is still quite a bit higher than other internet companies that are running about 50% domestic and 50% international. Is there a chance that you can get that lower, much closer to the G
componenttext: One, your tax rate of 34.5% or even, the 30% that you had historically is still quite a bit higher than other internet companies that are running about 50% domestic and 50% international. Is there a chance that you can get that lower, much closer to the Google or eBay rates that they see in near the 20% by different Irish, sandwich things? And on a second question, given the last 2 quarters of 49% and then 50% this quarter EBITDA margins, have you pretty -- are you willing to kind of throw out your 42% to 47% EBITDA margin guidance that you gave when you did the spin?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's Julie. I'll take those. So first, on the tax rate, and one thing to keep in mind up until December, end of December last year, we are part of Expedia and part of their tax planning and mobile IT strategy. And now that we are a standalone company and
componenttext: It's Julie. I'll take those. So first, on the tax rate, and one thing to keep in mind up until December, end of December last year, we are part of Expedia and part of their tax planning and mobile IT strategy. And now that we are a standalone company and have our own tax departments and are looking at where IP is located and what makes the best business sense, we're definitely looking into that. One thing that also placed into TripAdvisor's negative impact on the rates is that we're headquartered in Massachusetts, which has a higher tax rate than where some of the other players may be located. So we're working on it. There's a lot of lower tax rate and it is definitely part of our strategy going forward. Regarding the EBITDA margins, I want to remind you that we did not give that 42% to 47%. It was not guidance and/or long-term target model. It was just to illustrate the effect of the spend on our 2010 numbers. So we've had things like the additional G&A cost, the decrease in Expedia pricing. Those -- that impact was applied against 2010 just to give an of model. We are in the process of -- we've had a lot of movements in 2013, and excuse me, in 2012. We are actively looking for investment opportunities for sales and marketing, for our traffic diversification and so forth. And even from quarter-to-quarter, we are able to spend less or more in sales and marketing. And we're looking at what 2000 -- we're in the planning cipher 2013, and we'll come back to you on that on our Q4 call.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Lloyd Walmsley of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Lloyd Walmsley of Deutsche Bank.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could comment a bit. It looks like we saw big ramp in Expedia's general direct marketing expense in terms of the year-over-year growth in the third quarter. And obviously, they made it clear that they're adjusting and levels vis-à-v
componenttext: Just wondering if you could comment a bit. It looks like we saw big ramp in Expedia's general direct marketing expense in terms of the year-over-year growth in the third quarter. And obviously, they made it clear that they're adjusting and levels vis-à-vis, you guys. But I was just wondering at what point do you think you can be participating in some of that growth again from Expedia? And where do you think they're spending that incremental share as they accelerate to expand?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Perfectly fair interesting question. Unfortunately, I really don't have any insight into where Expedia's is expanding their funds on the marketing side. I would expect, as our -- presuming our traffic continues to grow at the rate we have been growi
componenttext: Sure. Perfectly fair interesting question. Unfortunately, I really don't have any insight into where Expedia's is expanding their funds on the marketing side. I would expect, as our -- presuming our traffic continues to grow at the rate we have been growing, one would naturally assume that Expedia would be spending more with us in incoming years. We've gone through the step function. We've brought things down to what we believe are much closer to kind of market rates. And now it's a bidding environment. And the degree to which we can get everyone to be bidding up for the traffic we have, we'll see that increase spend. I think Expedia, like our other plans, are very smart on traffic acquisition side. So we remain, the best of our knowledge, an incredibly important, valuable partner of theirs in terms of buying direct leads. Their sales and marketing line, I believe, encompasses quite a bit more than just the direct marketing. So in that -- in their marketing spend, it could well be in other areas that we don't participate in, TV, radio, whatever it might be. You have to ask them about that part.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Anthony DiClemente of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is from Anthony DiClemente of Barclays.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just as we look into 2013, I just wondered if you guys can bridge through for us the lapping or the anniversary effect of a number of the changes that you've already alluded to on this call and how we should think about maybe even just modeling through th
componenttext: Just as we look into 2013, I just wondered if you guys can bridge through for us the lapping or the anniversary effect of a number of the changes that you've already alluded to on this call and how we should think about maybe even just modeling through things like lapping through the CPC, step down, the site decluttering. Can you call it in those out as we model through for even just the first half of 2013 on revenue, at least that will be helpful for us.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: So we're trying to provide do some of that bridge in my prepared remarks by calling out things that were either one-time or not normal course of business. So FX and we forecast in constant currency. So anything that we talked about on a forward-looking ba
componenttext: So we're trying to provide do some of that bridge in my prepared remarks by calling out things that were either one-time or not normal course of business. So FX and we forecast in constant currency. So anything that we talked about on a forward-looking basis is using exchange rates as of today. So we're not trying to predict what's going to happen there. So you can make your own decision. So we've had some, just looking at Q3, some one-time, such as the Olympics. So that's 2% on overall rent on CPC, tax link revenue. And when you extrapolate that out, it's probably about 1.5% off of our total year-over-year growth rates. The site redesign is probably the largest one. As Steve mentioned, we lapsed that at the end of Q3. At that time, we were able to clearly see that it had negatively impacted our year-over-year growth rate by about 5% to 6%. So we would expect that trend to continue forward into Q4 and beyond. And then the other mention that we made was the Expedia pricing. Now that contracts anniversaries the date of the spend and we had said that originally, it's probably a 3% to 5% negative impact on revenue as of the last couple of quarters, we've been saying it's at the high-end of that range. So that cost, we'll anniversary that at the end of this quarter.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: And Julie, that's all helpful. One follow-up on the last one. Did you have a -- was there spending floor that was in place? And is there -- should we be concerned up like about the possibility of another step down after lapping the expiry of the post spin
componenttext: And Julie, that's all helpful. One follow-up on the last one. Did you have a -- was there spending floor that was in place? And is there -- should we be concerned up like about the possibility of another step down after lapping the expiry of the post spin contracts? Like can that, can Expedia spend step down again? Is that likely or unlikely?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think we put the agreement in place to make for a smooth transition from where both sides didn't quite know what would happen with the companies were unbundled, if you will. We think the prices have gotten much closer to market rates. So we're not forec
componenttext: I think we put the agreement in place to make for a smooth transition from where both sides didn't quite know what would happen with the companies were unbundled, if you will. We think the prices have gotten much closer to market rates. So we're not forecasting a big step down function. Regardless of what we forecast, clearly, it is a bit environment. So there are meaningful questions one get to ask Expedia and all the other bidders in terms of how much they're interested in growing their share, what are the competitive forces that are going to get the bids to go up. So yes, as Julie said, we anniversary the agreement. But obviously, we've known it's been coming for quite some time.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Peter Stabler of Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from Peter Stabler of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Going back to the property rank reporting data, where you have a test, 3 test markets, I think you said. Could you envision a situation where you would not elect to roll that out widely? It would seem like very valuable data, your spectrum of whether an R
componenttext: Going back to the property rank reporting data, where you have a test, 3 test markets, I think you said. Could you envision a situation where you would not elect to roll that out widely? It would seem like very valuable data, your spectrum of whether an RTA partner explicitly ask for it or not. And then secondly, wondered if you could comment on kind of the lifetime value of your reviews? You continue to add review content kind of hand over fifth. But at what point does the value kind of expire a little bit? I mean, the 6-year-old review is clearly not as valuable as the 6-month-old review. I wonder if you could just kind of comment on those trends.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. 2 good questions. So on bank reporting, I haven't heard any feedback from any of our test partners that say, "Thanks, but no thanks, we weren't really interested in this information." I think we more hear, "Wow, it's a lot of information, it's a lot
componenttext: Sure. 2 good questions. So on bank reporting, I haven't heard any feedback from any of our test partners that say, "Thanks, but no thanks, we weren't really interested in this information." I think we more hear, "Wow, it's a lot of information, it's a lot to digest." To put it into perspective and we have a client that's bidding on 100,000 properties times, call it, 20 different markets, that's just a lot of data to digest and make sense of. So we're having to be measured in our roll out for our client request basically. So I don't -- it's a little hard for me to imagine that situation where over time, we don't have this information available to everyone. But I'm a lot more cautious about trying to predict in which quarter it will be both available and consumed for everyone. To your second part of your question, lifetime value of the reviews. We hardly agree the 6-year-old review is perhaps nice to have on the site because it mentioned something that's unique to that review, a tip in the neighborhood or something like that, climbing on top of the hill to watch a beautiful sunset. The 6-year-old review really isn't part of our popularity index calculation anymore either Because it's so old and so much can change in the 6 years. Similarly, we have some hotels north of 8,000 review. And they may be all current but you still don't need 8,000 to have a lot of liquidity of opinion for that property. The beauty of what we're able to do with generating so many more reviews is sort of provide fantastic coverage on, not only the top properties in the city, but kind of all the properties in the city, the country, all the restaurants. So it's getting to the point where it's tough to find a hotel with the less than 50 reviews. And that's what we're getting pretty excited about because everyone can look at 5 reviews on a property and say, "What's the big deal?" With 50, you start to really understand what you're going to get when you stay there.  And the same applies restaurant and the same applies to tools and attractions and museums and everything else that goes into what folks are looking at. So sure, if you took the 6-year-old reviews off the site, no one would notice. The volume was so small anyways. it practically doesn't matter. We keep them on just as a convenient function for our current customers.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Heath Terry of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Heath Terry of Goldman Sachs.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could give us a sense of what you're seeing from a usage perspective within mobile, whether or not as the medium matures for you, whether you're seeing more transactional activity within mobile versus research and whether or no
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could give us a sense of what you're seeing from a usage perspective within mobile, whether or not as the medium matures for you, whether you're seeing more transactional activity within mobile versus research and whether or not the -- how different the segments hotel versus activities are within your mobile channels versus desktop?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm pretty sure that the activity is distinctly different. There's more non-hotel activity on the phone versus the desktop or tablet. Monetization is certainly a lot fewer people are clicking off to see the price. Perhaps, because they know when the
componenttext: Well, I'm pretty sure that the activity is distinctly different. There's more non-hotel activity on the phone versus the desktop or tablet. Monetization is certainly a lot fewer people are clicking off to see the price. Perhaps, because they know when they do that function on our mobile device right now, on the phone, it's a pretty painful experience in order to get back to the app and all that. So we'll let you know on the next call how the meta experience is being accepted by the user in the smartphone device and whether that's in fact, encouraging more commerce clicks, and in turn, more conversions. I still kind of standby my original comments in terms of the use case of the mobile phone. While some other apps or the OTA apps, if you find yourself in a city and you need a hotel room and you haven't done any advanced planning, you're just probably more in the "Hey, find me something close to where I am, and I'm going to book it and an OTA web app -- an OTA app can do that for you quite well. We're in the more expensive, the more time-consuming, the more enjoyable research experience, which generally happens long before the day of booking. So we believe our usage will continue to grow genetically a mobile. We believe will be able to fund specifically. We believe we'll be able to grow our amortization rate. But I am personally skeptical that we'll ever achieve the monetization rate that we have a desktop on the phones purely because of that usage case.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Herman Leung of Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Our next question is from Herman Leung of Susquehanna Financial.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Debok sitting in for Herman. So just a question on Facebook as a general. So could you discuss how the ROI from fiscal position was during the quarter? Maybe give some qualitative color on that? And then what otherwise, maybe some social ways in w
componenttext: This is Debok sitting in for Herman. So just a question on Facebook as a general. So could you discuss how the ROI from fiscal position was during the quarter? Maybe give some qualitative color on that? And then what otherwise, maybe some social ways in which you can acquire customers using the Facebook channel?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Facebook remains a meaningful channel to grow our brand awareness and to grow our membership. I'll try to be reasonably clear that we don't view it as a very large traffic acquisition channel. Certainly, not compared to a channel like Search. So
componenttext: Sure. So Facebook remains a meaningful channel to grow our brand awareness and to grow our membership. I'll try to be reasonably clear that we don't view it as a very large traffic acquisition channel. Certainly, not compared to a channel like Search. So you have folks on Facebook that are engaged in sharing and learning about what their friends are into, posting photos and the rest. And in many times, they're interested in interacting with our been, with our Cities I Visited or seeing status update from a friend about the trips that they've taken. Cities I've visited they did up to use it here joining TripAdvisor and you're telling us something about yourself, namely all of the different places that you've been. You're also giving us your friend network so that we can share all those places that you've been as data when your friends come and browse on TripAdvisor. We cap Facebook as a member acquisition channel, is quite strong for us because we spend a certain amount to advertise our map and TripAdvisor applications. We get a certain uptake. That's had a somewhat expensive rate, sort of qualitative because it's just a member, it's not a travel booking yet. But because of what those folks are doing with the app, it's generating invitations to other users. It's generating status feeds. It's generating open raft items. And I can go through the long due list of Facebook viral channels, which in turn are generating lot more members for us for free we're not having to pay to acquire. So we continue our spent and that channel because it helps us grow our membership and it helps us grow our social content namely knowing where your friends had been to in order to make progress on our social and personalization efforts, which I've touched upon. So think of it as building a huge database of travelers, travelers who happen to be Facebook connected. We're learning more and more about that. Whether or not they've been to TripAdvisor yet or teaching them about TripAdvisor and we're getting the click-through rates in the e-mails, let's say "Hey, they're interested in this. So they're coming back. "Of and then the longer-term question is, then -- through that mechanism, will they be converted to the more domain direct, the more brain dead association. We see positive signs, but the jury is still out to buy several quarters, in our opinion, as to whether that's going to move the needle as much as we hope going forward.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Brian Nowak from Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question is from Brian Nowak from Nomura.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: The first one is with Expedia kind of looking to grow the agency business in the U.S., I was wondering if you could talk about any differences and cost per lick or monetization that you see an agency dominated markets versus merchant hotel dominated marke
componenttext: The first one is with Expedia kind of looking to grow the agency business in the U.S., I was wondering if you could talk about any differences and cost per lick or monetization that you see an agency dominated markets versus merchant hotel dominated markets? And then the second one, hunkers dear about I know there's been a lot of focus on the kind of the conversion of your OTA partners as a focal point in the last quarter. So I was just curious as any commentary about the direction of the ROI and your partner conversion this quarter versus last quarter?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on the Expedia Agency business, we're certainly aware of their offering choice to their consumers. We don't have inside information, but it stands to reason one of the opportunities for them is to increase their conversion rate even if the margin
componenttext: Sure. So on the Expedia Agency business, we're certainly aware of their offering choice to their consumers. We don't have inside information, but it stands to reason one of the opportunities for them is to increase their conversion rate even if the margin or the finances behind it might be different. And I say might because again I'm not part of it. Our respective interests are perfectly aligned because if offering the payout checkout feature improves conversion, then they're making more money per, not necessarily per booking, but per lead I send them because of the higher conversion rate. Therefore, they can afford to pay me as much as they were before or even more, if they dip into some of their efficiency numbers. So we don't view the percentage uptake of their agency business as bad in any way, should it be strong in certain markets. If it helps, another way to look at it is if it helps them to be competitive in certain markets, where they didn't have the product offering before, fantastic, because then they'll be able to bid more for traffic in those markets. Again, the conversion rate is expected to make up for any loss in merchant revenues. It's actually a little bit related to the OTA conversion, the second part of your question. So when we look at the leads that we send to our clients, I don't really ask them, are my leads better converting than a Google or somebody else? I look to see on a per dollar spend basis, do we generate more profit for you folks than your other channels? And we continue to hear that our clients are bidding independently i.e. they're not favoring TripAdvisor over Google or vice versa, they'll spend whenever they can get the best ROI. So if a TripAdvisor lead converts of that twice the rate of a Google lead, then they're probably paying twice as much for it, then the converse is true to we are comparing the actual CPC, or the actual conversion independently that we the question you want to ask. It's of the "Hey, how's the efficiency of TripAdvisor as a traffic source to these clients. " And while every one of our clients, no doubt, would like an even more efficient source, they're all free to lower the bits at any point, which will get them less traffic, but presumably, a little bit more efficient. And they're not doing that. So Dave -- it's always changing, but seems like they found a happy balance in terms of the efficiency that they're willing to spend on TripAdvisor and the conversion that, that drives.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: All right, there. Well, as we closed with before, we're very proud of the quarter and we see trends going forward that we very much like. I want to thank everyone for joining our call today. I mean, I really want to thank all the TripAdvisor in place arou
componenttext: All right, there. Well, as we closed with before, we're very proud of the quarter and we see trends going forward that we very much like. I want to thank everyone for joining our call today. I mean, I really want to thank all the TripAdvisor in place around the globe for their hard work throughout the quarter and we know we can count on it going forward. So we've made some great progress on our growth initiatives. Very excited about it, and we look forward to updating all of you on our progress in early 2013. Thanks again.
